HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 25, 1928

SCHEIBEL TO LEAD
JAY TRACK TEAM
Scheibel, star
Herman
miler and two miler, was
elected captain of the 1929
Johns Hopkins track team
last Monday night at the annual track banquet. at the
Southern Hotel.
Retiring Captain Edgar Viveil acted as toastmaster.
Some of the speakers who
were heard from were: Dr.
Van Orman, Coach Ridgely
Edwards, Waldo Hambleton,
Mr. Henry Iddins and the retiring letter men.
The track men agreed that
the 1928 season was the most
successful in many years.

WYATT NAMED COLONEL
OF R. O. T. C. UNIT
Fibel, Embury, Banks, Medenbach, Gibbs, Wolff
other Officers

LAST NEWS-LETTER
TO APPEAR JUNE II
The NEWS-LETTER wishes
to announce that this issue
will be the last one to appeal
during the current academic
year, with the exception of
the June Week number. This
procedure has been adopted by
the NEWS-LETTER because of
the final examinations.
The last issue will appear
on Monday, June 11, in the
midst of the June Week activities. It will be of usual
size.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 25, 1928

FANTASTIC SCENES IN VIEW AS JUNE
WEEK FESTIVITIES NEAR REALIZATION
Happy, smiling faces relieved of
exam worries, hearts equally light
that dance in step with flying feet,
music that would make the very
leaves on the trees sway to its palpitating rhythm, charming companions arrayed in most exquisite attire, gentle breaths of air that call
to rest and sweetest enjoyment, and
above all a glorious white moon—
such are the scenes which the June
Week celebrants will enter upon in
two weeks' time. This most delightful event of the year entices
again to participation undergraduates, graduates and alumni.

Then there are those dances—
with refreshments at the _Maryland
Casualty and a buffet supper at the
Alcazar. Syncopation—and how!
Tea dances, informal dances, a
veritable whirl initiated by the Last
Cotillon and closed with the Jun
Ball—alas, all too soon. The Ball
climax of all the year's many!
dances, will last until long after the,
first bright streaks of dawn have
played about the skylights of the
Alcazar!

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 25, 1928

SCHEIBEL TO LEAD
JAY TRACK TEAM
Scheibel, star
Herman
miler and two miler, was
elected captain of the 1929
Johns Hopkins track team
last Monday night at the annual track banquet. at the
Southern Hotel.
Retiring Captain Edgar Viveil acted as toastmaster.
Some of the speakers who
were heard from were: Dr.
Van Orman, Coach Ridgely
Edwards, Waldo Hambleton,
Mr. Henry Iddins and the retiring letter men.
The track men agreed that
the 1928 season was the most
successful in many years.

WYATT NAMED COLONEL
OF R. O. T. C. UNIT
Fibel, Embury, Banks, Medenbach, Gibbs, Wolff
other Officers

LAST NEWS-LETTER
TO APPEAR JUNE II
The NEWS-LETTER wishes
to announce that this issue
will be the last one to appeal
during the current academic
year, with the exception of
the June Week number. This
procedure has been adopted by
the NEWS-LETTER because of
the final examinations.
The last issue will appear
on Monday, June 11, in the
midst of the June Week activities. It will be of usual
size.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 25, 1928

FANTASTIC SCENES IN VIEW AS JUNE
WEEK FESTIVITIES NEAR REALIZATION
Happy, smiling faces relieved of
exam worries, hearts equally light
that dance in step with flying feet,
music that would make the very
leaves on the trees sway to its palpitating rhythm, charming companions arrayed in most exquisite attire, gentle breaths of air that call
to rest and sweetest enjoyment, and
above all a glorious white moon—
such are the scenes which the June
Week celebrants will enter upon in
two weeks' time. This most delightful event of the year entices
again to participation undergraduates, graduates and alumni.

Then there are those dances—
with refreshments at the _Maryland
Casualty and a buffet supper at the
Alcazar. Syncopation—and how!
Tea dances, informal dances, a
veritable whirl initiated by the Last
Cotillon and closed with the Jun
Ball—alas, all too soon. The Ball
climax of all the year's many!
dances, will last until long after the,
first bright streaks of dawn have
played about the skylights of the
Alcazar!
